item.title: Plugin management
item.content:encoded: Fun idea: A protocol that programs can implement to allow their plugins to be managed by the system’s package manager.

item.title: Downtime
item.content:encoded: If downtime is inevitable, then it might as well be on schedule.

item.title: Walk speed
item.content:encoded:
Theory: The reason player characters move at different speeds from NPCs is because the PC has been calibrated on the player’s perception. PCs can’t move as slow as NPCs because it would feel sluggish, and NPCs can’t move as fast as PCs because it wouldn’t look realistic.

It occurs to me that twitter will probably silently nuke shit out of this tweet. If you are one of the lucky few to see it, hi!

item.title: Good code
item.content:encoded: Write good code to write good code.

item.title: Punishing players
item.content:encoded: It’s current year and we’re still hell-bent on punishing players for not playing our games correctly instead of just shoving them into their own world where they can play however they like.

item.title: AI skimming
item.content:encoded: It seems like AI is really good at appearing correct at a glance. It’s almost like it’s being trained by humans that are just skimming the results.

item.title: Social engagement
item.content:encoded: I have reservations about using retweets/boosts/likes/favorites, but Mastodon seems to be less psychotic about them, so I might use them more there.

item.title: Software design
item.content:encoded: When a software’s design is poorly understood, the only thing users have to go off of is whatever they’re allowed to do.

item.title: Dead project
item.content:encoded: A perfectly correct but dead project is better than a mostly correct but living project only if the project is already completely finished.

item.title: Little brain
item.content:encoded: So much software to write, so little brain to write them.

item.title: If-expression
item.content:encoded: An if-expression that is too long to be one-lined should just be an if-statement.
